quoteLast: by the clock in the little tailor shop at his left, and he must meet his appointment at a quarter of five or lose his job. Luckily, he had planned to get there ahead of time--and she would be back in ten minutes--so he’d keep his date all right.
title: A Merry Scout
author: Brett, Edna Payson; Riley, Garada Clark [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: I went back to New York and looked it up in the public library. On Friday, June 9, 1916, the sun rose at
quoteLast: On Wednesday, June 9, 1926, the sun rose at five twenty-eight. So that’s that.”
title: The Bellamy trial
author: Hart, Frances Noyes, 1890-1943

quoteFirst: Twilight also affords us so much additional light that we may safely assert that in any given place on the earth’s surface there is much more “daylight” than “night.” For example, on the 30th, daybreak occurs at
quoteLast: , and twilight ends at 7:18 p. m., thus giving three hours and nine minutes in which to lengthen our daily toil, if we choose so to do. In the same latitude, and in different latitudes, as was shown in THE CHAUTAUQUAN for June, the length of twilight varies, so that in some instances the entire night is only twilight.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, July 1884, No. 10
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]
